Key Arguments: The legislation may exacerbate existing divisions among students and society by limiting open debate.
Exemptions for certain groups (e.g., professional news content, government content) could create an 'information elite' and erode public trust.
The definitions of 'harm' and 'hatred' are vague and could be abused, leading to selective application of penalties.
The legislation may lead to self-censorship and further polarization.
Main Themes: Concerns about exemptions and information control
Vague definitions leading to potential abuse
Impact on education and student expression
Notable Quotes: The concept of free and fair speech has already been eroded to the point where robust discussion is no longer possible.
I fear this will create an ‘information elite’ who control what is and isn’t acceptable to say in society.
Unless the definition of harm is something everyone can agree on, I fear the term will be abused.
Nowhere in history has censorship ever led to better outcomes for citizens.
